title: What will be the closing yield for 10-year U.S. Treasuries on 31 August 2019?
preds: There are two days left for the 31st of August. The interest today is 1.52% and assuming an average change of 0.07% every two days, this leaves the 1.70% mark at 2.5 sigmas,  which assuming a normal distribution gives a 0.7% (rounded to 1%) probability of being reached. Of course this is a very coarse and naive model, but probably might be good enough.
The yield has been below 1.7 for over two weeks now, so it seems likely to stay unless some drastic news comes out today or tomorrow to push it back up.

Speaking to the Outside View, my random walk model [1] which utilizes, historical frequencies of price movements, estimates a 99% chance of the lowest bucket. More specifically to this case, the 10-year yield has been depressed in large part due to the recent escalation in the US-China trade war. Since it is unlikely that progress will be made in the next week (US and China are scheduled to resume talks next month), the probability of a short term recover remains low. On the other hand, Trump provided positive comments at the G7: ""We will see what happens but I think we will make a deal," Trump said."[2] Therefore I am not reducing to 1%. Reducing the lowest bucket from 90%. [1] https://github.com/EmilDim/GJO/blob/master/RandomWalk.ipynb
[2] https://www.cnn.com/2019/08/26/politics/donald-trump-g7-monday-intl/index.html
no reason to expect a strong uptick, especially in a time of inverted yield curve
Unless Trump and Xi become fast friends, this is going to remain <1.70 by the end of August.
10 yr is currently at 1.54 with 7 days left.

Five more trading days, 18 basis point headwind, trade war escalation (addtl tariffs announced after market close), concerns about global growth, limited willingness to “risk on” in the markets, and low liquidity in the summer months... yeah, I have a tough time seeing this one coming back to 1.7%.  Do I believe Treasury’s are in a bubble - YES
Do I believe that negative real rates in a US economy that is growing at 2% are ridiculous -YES
Do I think this will change materially in the next 7 days - NOPE

I'm trying the separate out the oddities of the international Bond Market in a Negative rate environment while tempering my concern about a full recession with the thought that the Dems need to kill the economy on paper to have a prayer in 2020 and while that is a poor basis to make business decisions on, it seems to be today's reality.

The trade war has ratcheted up a notch with China's announcement of additional tariffs, and Trumps ordering of US businesses to move to other countries. https://www.wsj.com/articles/global-stocks-rise-with-all-eyes-on-the-fed-11566547507?mod=hp_lead_pos2&mod=article_inline&mod=hp_lead_pos2
Hedging the forecast on suspicion the FED may flip the script tomorrow.

Outside view: The latest results from my Geometric Random Walk model (which can be found here [1]) are: 99% for <1.7. However, it is worth to consider the model's blind spots. One drawback of this method is that it assumes price volatility is constant at its long-term average. In reality financial volatilities tend to change over time and be clustered. The recent period of high volatility means it's more likely that the volatility in the near future will be higher than the one assumed by the model.  Inside View:  News about the Trump administration considering fiscal stimulus measures raise the upside risk and increase the probability of yields going back up. Therefore, I raise the probability of the price swinging back above 1.7 compared to the model. [1] https://github.com/EmilDim/GJO/blob/master/RandomWalk.ipynb

Current pressures facing FED [incl: US and dollar as perceived safe haven], global economic outlook seen to be worsening - technical view of chart shows since July sell off from 2% the gap down took it below 1.75% - Powell is unable/unwilling to go against market at the moment - international traders looking for safety [away from negative yield in Europe] - not long to go on this one but could even be below 1.5% by the time 31st Aug come around

Most of the market is fixated on inverted bond yields; recession indicators abounding. 
Most of the talk is other central banks QE in negative terratory.  Japan, Europe. 
Turkey lira depreciation, argentina, Brazil - even the secondary markets are folding.  So while there is certainly a good chance that there are some upside moves,  I think the overall trend is down.   Going to 95-5 to avoid a 2 on volatility, but I will be edging up as we grow closer, I suspect.

In less than one month the 10-yr US Treasury yield has dropped from over 2% to a bit over 1.5%.  Going back to November of 2018 the trend has been down.  So with less than two weeks to go until August 31 it may seem obvious that the correct answer to this question is "less than 1.7."  The problem is that a single tweet about a trade deal with China could cause a snap back in long-term interest rates, which could easily exceed 1.7%.  So this has become a bet on whether or not, and when, Trump decides to call a truce with China. The lack of predictability will not go away.  The global economy is weakening due to fear.  While the fear factor will ebb and flow, it will continue.   It is Trump's favored method of manipulation, of markets as well as voters.  Now he is demanding that the Federal Reserve lower short-term interest rates immediately by 1%, and also begin quantitative easing.  This would give the president room to continue the tariff war.  Neither the Fed nor the business community wants a continuing trade war.  And the Fed won't react to the presidential tweets, at least not quickly.  The uncertainty has caused the price of gold to break out on the upside.  Nobody knows how this will end, but the markets are predicting that it could end badly. So my bet, which is really just a guess, is that Trump will wait until at least September.
updating for time decay and current yield
The yeald is at 1.55 as of Friday...

10-year Treasury yield hits lowest since Trump election after Fed hints at rate cut
By Sunny Oh Published: June 19, 2019 3:27 p.m. ET
Share 10-year Treasury yield falls to lowest since Nov. 8 2016
Time (EDT)16 Aug8:004:00
BX:TMUBMUSD10Y
BX:TMUBMUSD02Y
BX:TMUBMUSD30Y
-7.5%-5.0%-2.5%0.0%2.5%5.0% U.S. Treasury yields fell sharply on Wednesday after the policy statement from the Federal Reserve’s two-day meeting suggested the central bank could cut interest rates later this year.
What are Treasurys doing? The 10-year Treasury note yield TMUBMUSD10Y, +0.00%  fell 3.6 basis points to 2.023%, its lowest closing level since Nov. 8 2016, the day when Donald Trump scored a stunning presidential election victory against Democratic contender Hillary Clinton. The 2-year Treasury note yield TMUBMUSD02Y, +0.00%, sensitive to shifting expectations for Fed policy, plunged 10.9 basis points to 1.758%, the lowest since November 2017. The 30-year bond rate TMUBMUSD30Y, +0.00%  was down 1.5 basis points to 2.537%, its lowest since October of 2016. Debt prices move in the opposite direction of yields.
1.55, with 10 business days left. What could get the yield to rebound >1.70 during that time?
Leaving 5% for an old style "dead cat bounce" chart pattern.
Now OUR chart is inverted. Emotions. Psychological support levels gone.

Continued decline in yields due to a flight to safety. Updating despite softening of trade tensions given muted market reactions. The markets seem to be responding the “feedback loop” by keeping prices and yields low knowing that a rally will only embolden further action on China. I think this is the main reason Treasury yields are quick to fall on bad news, but slow to rally on good news. My expectation is that this dynamic will continue until a meaningful deal is reached (seems unlikely in <1 month).  What is so interesting is how these changes have essentially eliminated the real term premium (compensation for holding the 10 year note above inflation expectations). That premium sits at zero currently. Since the next Core PCE release isn’t until 8/30, I think markets will continue anchoring to the lower number of 1.6%. That and concerns about global growth and the relative strength of US Treasuries should keep yields low. On the other hand, further degradation of the markets could force the administration to soften their stance which would drive a rally. The PBOC could also start selling in an effort to weaken the yuan, but this seems unlikely given it is not a proportional response to the administration walking back on some tariffs

This has to be a top-down forecast. While the arrow is pointing down over the mid-term, there is now wide agreement on this and a lot of bad news is price in. With the YTM at 1.7020% at the time of writing, I thus allocated equal probability the two first buckets.  Note that under the current scenarios where the general market perception seems to have moved quickly in recently weeks (as demonstrated by the recent drop in 10 yr US govvies since End July), a more quant-based forecast makes little sense.

Chinese capital flight will fuel gold rise, and US treasuries.  Separately, crack down on HK will make a huge flight to safety.   German bond yields negative; Sterling due a rate cut.  Switzerland down. Unfortunately,  I think recent predictions have gone too high on the under 1.7.  No value for the prediction.   Volatility is too high to be sure.   Sticking for now. Ooof - and as soon as I post, tarrifs are delayed... removing a big driver down.
Lomg term the rate will rise to over 2, possibly over 2.3.  The market is very jittery now.  It is below 1.7, but will recover and then fall et cetera.  Trump will tweet something to affect it again.

1. Flight to safety.
2.  Low oil costs. 
Low oil costs work through the entire you economy.  Additionally since the money is staying here, boosts economy.
3. Low % trade resolution.

Adjusting down given the recent volatility in the market and the steep fall in yields. Historical data suggests that each round of trade escalation and de-escalation puts downside pressure on yields with limited rebound. In other words - despite the US and China being no closer to a trade deal than they were last Spring, the 10 year yield is lower. That gives me confidence that, while yields may hold flat, a rebound seems less likely.  Risk seems firmly concentrated on the downside, especially given low inflation expectations.

Updated forecast based on last few days of data assuming a random walk and a log normal distribution.  My prediction interval has become more restricted than previously and I added some prob to the 2.1 to 2.3 range.
10 yr is at 1.86 after dropping significantly in the last few days.

In my previous forecast, I cited the impact of a potential change in trade negotiations. I didn’t expect this to be such an immediate risk, but a fall to 1.89% on the news is getting my attention. The tariffs will not go into effect until sept 1 so I don’t want to over-react.

Ten year walk to establish a base line. Given that the 10-year is on a declining path and reductions in interest rates sometimes come with co-movements, I'm going to weight downward a little. Crowd has 4%, 18%, 57%, 18%, 2%, which appears too concentrated at the current level, particularly given we are within 12 basis points of the second option and also not giving enough coverage for the risk of movement, given historical yields.  0.098: Bin 1 - <1.7
0.224: Bin 2 - 1.7 to <=1.9
0.34: Bin 3 - 1.9+ to <2.1
0.217: Bin 4 - 2.1 to <=2.3
0.121: Bin 5 - 2.3+ "As we can see, the fed funds rate and the one-year Treasury rate track each other very closely. Although it is still debatable whether the Fed leads or follows the market, movements in the policy rate are associated with similar movements in short-term interest rates." In contrast, the interest rate on a 10-year Treasury bond does not appear to move as closely with the fed funds rate. While there appears to be some co-movement, the 10-year interest rate appears to follow its own declining path."[1] [1] https://www.stlouisfed.org/on-the-economy/2017/october/increases-fed-funds-rate-impact-other-interest-rates

Dollar strength, further weakness in the EU are short term blocks to higher US rates. Possible US inflation also seems outside the time frame needed to raise rates before this Q closes.
https://www.wsj.com/articles/as-fed-prepares-to-cut-rates-some-see-path-to-higher-yields-11564574405

Despite the robust employment data, the Fed cut the short term rate by 25 basis point.  A rate cut tends to increase inflation.  It is also used to combat recession.  Both of these factors tend to increase the long term yield. The current 10 year yield has already factored in a 25 basis point cut.  Since there is unlikely another cut before the end of August, the 10 year yield will likely stay within the trading range in the past month.

This is an interesting question and I’ve finally had enough time to give it some in depth thought (now that I’ve sunk my ship on fed funds rate question lol).  I’m going to try and break this into a smaller question since 5 bins can be a bit intimidating. First - “how likely are rates to be above 2%?” The 10 year is primarily driven by 2 factors:
1. Expectations for future inflation
2. Demand/Supply of 10-year notes Within the 2nd bullet, there are a few factors that affect supply and demand. 
1. Treasury issuance
2. Flight to quality
3. Fed action on short term rates
4 uncertainty about future policy (term premium) Looking at 24 different scenarios related to the Fed, Brexit, and the US China trade war, I came up with 55% of scenarios involve yields less than 2, 25% involve yields right around 2 (1.9-2.1), and 20% with yields below 1.9. These estimates are tricky because the implicitly assume a longer time frame than the question.  Keeping my observations more short term, the st dev of the 10-year yield is low (need to do some more research) so I’m focusing on big events that could shift it in the next 30ish days. The biggest (I think) is a 50bps rate cut that would posture a more dovish position from the fed and encourage a risk-on sentiment in markets, lowering yields. Brexit and China are important but feel longer term.  That 50bps cut is informing my 2.1 to >2.3 bins. The <1.7 to 1.9 is a function of slowing inflation expectations (probably reinforced by the Feds statement and widely agreed upon by CBs). The 1.9 to 2.1 bin represents my expectations that the market has priced in the big shifts already.  Will update based on the Feds rate decision, their statement and meeting minutes, a more quantitative look at rate movements over 30 day periods, and any news.

The USGG10YR index is now largely depends on how many rate cuts will be implemented on 7/31/2019. 80% of the market is forcasting a 0.25 basis point cut. This will probably lead to a short term rebound of stock market. Forcing the cash flow to flow back to the stock market for a short period. Though the USGG10YR index and SPX index have been diverging for quite a while, about 6 months. But still the rate cut will affect cash flow and cause fluctuation in treasury yields.
ECB decision today has already moved the US 10 yr rate higher.  FED move to a single 0.25 % rate cut and an expectation of fewer cuts in the future may continue to move the 10 yr higher.
Updated based on the last few days of 10 Year Yield closings using my RW model
This week 2.05, 2.08, upward pressure from pending FED rate cut, downward by the fears of an​ economic slowdown.

Outside view: Results from Monte Carlo with Random Walks based on a year and a half of daily % change base rates. 1, 20, 49, 27, 4 Inside view: Factors to consider and watch
* Rate cut - Fed is about to cut short term interest rates in the end of July. The long-term rate is closely related to inflation and the long-term outlook for the economy. A rate cut pushes inflation higher, thus placing upward pressure on the 10-year. The rate cut is priced in but markets will move depending on how much the Fed decides to cut (50 or 25 basis points).
* Trade - progress in the trade negotiations with China would push the rate higher, all else being equal. Data: https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/data-chart-center/interest-rates/Pages/TextView.aspx?data=yield

Looks like it's dipping back up a little bit after a downward trend. 2.13 right now.

10 yr yield is at 2.124% currently. Adjusting up the probability 2.1% or greater yield.
The 1 percenters will not be able to continue to fool most of the american people for long.

The way I see it, fundamentals in the equity markets are primarily driving the 10 yr yield right now. Lower rates (likely cut in july) reduce the discount applied to future earnings and earnings themselves have been moderately strong. This is creating a shift out of longer duration fixed income into equities and pushing 10 year rates higher. I think there is a ceiling however, and we are very near it.  Some factors that come to mind:
- continuing trade concerns are dragging on investment, costs, and likely (to some degree) earnings
- low inflation will probably keep a lid on the 10 year 2.2% maybe)
- slowing global growth increases the flight to safety risk 
- with over $13T in global debt yielding negative, it is hard to ignore the relative value of the US Treasury market All those factors support the downside. On the upside:
- a sustained global equities rally would likely push rates to the 2.3-2.5% range ( what we saw in Q1, 2019)
- quick trade resolution - low probability given systemic disagreements
- inflation kicks up through increased spending in the US. Right labor market could begin to really pull workers in (i.e. non-employment decreases in a meaningful way) - see Howard Marks “This Time It’s Different” I assign a higher probability to 1 and 2 in the list above, but given the length of the tight labor market, short time frame, and growth concerns the first list seems more rational. Want to do some quantitative analysis on rate volatility’s before I update too much. More using this as an opportunity to lay out my rationale and redistribute a few hasty updates.

This is an update from my baseline forecast [1].   The robust employment gain in June makes a rate cut less likely for the July Fed meeting [2].  It is less likely that the 10-year treasury yield will follow the recent rapid reduction of 28 percentage point per month. I am reducing the chance of getting to less than 1.7% significantly. Trend has been downward for the ten yr(10 basis pts) despite being upward for the 1 month(also 10 basis pts) for the last week. This could foreshadow a more abrupt decrease in the rate as the feds July decision nears. But, who knows.
More informed, I'm tapering between the buckets from my broader 1st prediction. If the FED is going to cut rates at the end of July, which I don't expect btw, the yield will go up >2.10 level.

As I write this the yield is about 2.00 on the 10 year.  It is unlikely the Fed move on rates will come before the Aug forecast date.  Therefore I expect the yield to continue to fall in the 1.9 to 2.1 range.  The change will come in the Fall when interest rates will be reduced.
Adjusting for recent moves. Current yield 2.01. adjusted highest range 2.3 down 2%

The 10 year is primarily a gauge of US inflation expectations. According to the Survey of Professional Forecasters, Core PCE (inflation excluding food and energy) is expected to be 1.7% - 1.9% in Q2 and Q3 of 2019.  An increase in inflation would likely drive the yield up as would a rate increase (low probability) or a major step towards resolution in the trade dispute with China. That being said, I share JP Morgan's directional sentiment given more recent developments with the caveat that a July rate cut will push the yield higher
(https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-06-02/jpmorgan-cuts-u-s-10-year-yield-target-to-1-75-from-2-45)

My forecast is based on the yield history of the 10-year Treasuries in 2018 and 2019 [1], with the full understanding that past performances do not guarantee the future. I generated a plot of the daily yield of the 10-year Treasuries from 2018 to 2019. (I wish I could show the plot which would have made the following description easier and clearer.)  In the plot, one can divide the behavior of the yield into 4 regimes.   The yield gradually increased from January to November 2018 (Regime 1).  This was when the fed rate increased from 1.5% to 2.25%.  From mid-November to now, the yield decreased in 3 distinct steps: a gradual decrease from mid-January to mid-March 2019 (Regime 3) sandwiched between two rapid reductions (November to December 2018 – Regime 2, and mid-April to mid-June 2019 – Regime 4).  I am focusing on the 3 regimes of decreasing yields.  Interestingly the rates of the rapid decrease in Regimes 2 and 4 are very similar, about 0.28 percentage points per month while the one in the middle (Regime 3) is only 0.063 percentage points per month.  The question is whether the 10-year treasury yield will continue the rapid decrease as in Regimes 2 and 4, or switch to the much lower reduction rate as in Regime 3. or somewhere in between. If the rate reduction in the next two months follows the rapid rate (as in Regimes 2 and 4), the yield would be reduced to 1.54% (2.1-0.56).  If the rate reduction follows the slower rate (as in Regime 3), the yield would be reduced to 1.97% (2.1-0.126).   I use these two yields to bracket the forecast yield for 31 August 2019.  Given the continuing trend in the 10-year treasury yield, it is very unlikely that the yield will be above 2.3.  There is a slight chance that the yield becomes stable - 4%.  I will give the other 3 choices equal probability, for now. [1] https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/data-chart-center/interest-rates/Pages/TextView.aspx?data=yield

The Fed is behind the markets. By hiking too far, too fast, now delaying the corrective cuts, they are slowing the economy. Given the short time frame for the question, and the current rate level, yields are very likely to be where they are today, or slightly lower by the deadline.

Fed is in rate cutting cycle for first time in a decade Bonds have been sniffing out a recession while stocks are still at all time highs. I think the big drop in yields continues as data worsens, bond market was right, and we start seeing real fed easing and bad econ data out of europe and finally US starting in August.  I think with a recession being sniffed out by bonds already, rates take out 2016 lows easily, and market realizes we are going to ZIRP. Notice how the Fed has replaced « zero bound » with « effective lower bond », aka DiMartino booth and Dave Rosenberg argument that they are prepping us for ZIRP.  These are just some reasons

My model for U.S. 10-year yield suggests an equilibrium level of 2.80% so I think the bias for yields would be higher, but if the Fed cuts rates 50 basis points in July as many expect, I think it will be difficult for yields to rise all the way to 2.80%. I think the bias is higher, but only slightly so.

Rare for these rates to move very fast.  Pressure to keep rates moving down is dominant and the Fed seems split down the middle on rates with the President's pressure probably putting downward pressure on rates.
